title: Error: Returned error: Cannot get state root with uncommitted checkpoints

body: faced the same issue

Nice, Arch Linux :)

I think we'll need to investigate this. @davidmurdoch is this a Ganache error?

@davidmurdoch it still does not work with it.only, shows same error. I do not remember why I did not upgrade for the newer Node version, maybe because in past testrpc did not want to work with newer version.
@vitaliy-kuzmich can you try updating truffle to v5.1.14 and try again?

@davidmurdoch 
Truffle v5.1.14 (core: 5.1.14)
Solidity v0.5.16 (solc-js)
Node v13.9.0
Web3.js v1.2.1

That error message still remains. 


@vitaliy-kuzmich Hmmm, I'm still unable to reproduce the issue. Are you able to create a minimal reproduction repository (or upload a zip/archive and share a link) so I can debug the same exact configuration and code that is exhibiting this behavior?
@davidmurdoch was you able to reproduce it before truffle  v5.1.14 ?  What should I include into zip  ? My  .npm registry ?
@kostysh what is your system environment ?

I was not able to reproduce this issue with truffle 5.1.14 or 5.1.11.

You don't need to include any `node_modules` folders, but do be sure to include the project's lock file (`yarn.lock`, `package-lock.json` or `npm-shrinkwrap.json`) if present.

@davidmurdoch  Can you explain how are you going to debug it ? Maybe share some links ? Because I did not know how to put breakpoints in truffle.

[reproducer.tar.gz](https://github.com/trufflesuite/truffle/files/4268601/reproducer.tar.gz)

@vitaliy-kuzmich What version of `ganache-cli` did you use for these tests? I noticed in `run-rpc.sh` you have `/full path here/ganache-cli` but `ganache-cli` isn't defined in your `package.json`.

If you have `ganache-cli` installed globally (which is normal), run `ganache-cli --version` in your terminal to output that version.
@davidmurdoch Ganache CLI v6.9.1 (ganache-core: 2.10.2)

I'm able to reproduce this now. The reason I couldn't reproduce before is because the bug only happens when the account involved in the transfer is holding VERY large amount of ether, `999999999999999999999999999999999999999999999999999999999999999999999999999999999999999999` qualifies. :-D

At first glance this appears to be caused by an `ethereumjs-vm` bug (probably two bugs). The first bug is that `ethereumjs-vm` can't properly compute very large numbers. The other is that when an opcode throws an exception the vm's internal checkpoint stack isn't reverted enough times.

Or... it's a ganache-core bug. An easy fix for you right now is to reduce your  account's ether amount.

As for how to debug this... It's a bit convoluted:

 * I cloned `ganache-cli`
 * modified `lib.js` to reference my locally cloned `ganache-core` instead of the `node_modules` version.
 * I start up `ganache-cli` via `node --inspect /path/to/ganache-cli/cli.js`.
 * I then opened `ganache-core` in Visual Studio Code and set relevant breakpoints there.
 * I then attached to the modified `ganache-cli` (via Visual Studio Code) node debugger (Ctrl+Shift+P, select `>Debug:Attach to Node Process`)

Now when I run `truffle test` the debugger will pause on my breakpoints and I can inspect variables and step through as needed.
Related issue: https://github.com/ethereumjs/ethereumjs-vm/issues/672
@davidmurdoch thanks for debug tips!

@davidmurdoch but wait, my script worked since testrpc times, is it mean that new changes chat came with eth-js related things, broke bignumber in js ? Or bignumber is not part of this ecosystem anymore?
I believe they added an upper limit recently (in the past 6 months) because some operations require the data fit in a specific byte length.
@vitaliy-kuzmich is this issue still causing trouble for you?

Closing this for issue maintenance.

Let us know if there's more that's actionable for Truffle here and we can reopen. Thanks again!
